"Now faith is being sure of what we hope for, being convinced of what we do not see" ‚úùÔ∏è (Heb 11:1)

üëâ True faith is like mailing a letter - you drop it in the box and let it go. Doubt holds onto a corner of the letter and wonders why no reply comes. üìÆ I have letters in my desk written weeks ago - but because I wasn't sure about the address or content, they're still there. They help no one until I let them go, trusting the mail carrier.

This is how real faith works. It gives our problems to God, and then He acts. Psalm 37:5 says: "Commit your way to the Lord, trust also in Him, and He will act." But He won't act until we commit. Faith is receiving - better yet, taking - God's offered gifts. We can believe, come, commit, and rest... but we won't fully experience blessings until we start receiving and abiding in Him.

üìù Dr. Payson wrote to an anxious mother about her son:

"You worry too much. After praying for him and committing him to God, shouldn't your anxiety stop? üíå The command 'Be anxious for nothing' has no limits - just like 'Cast all your cares on Him.' If we throw our burdens on someone else, can they still weigh us down?

If we bring worries back from prayer, we didn't truly leave them there. üôè Here's my test: if after giving something to God, I can walk away like Hannah - no longer sad or anxious - that's proof I prayed in faith. But if I carry the burden away, my faith wasn't fully at work."
